Ōhinetahi valley is situated at the head of [[Lyttelton Harbour]] while the [[Port Hills]] rise above Ōhinetahi.<ref name="Potts1882">{{cite book |last= Potts |first= Thomas Henry |authorlink= Thomas Potts |title= Out in the open: a budget of scraps of natural history, gathered in New Zealand |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=VRkAAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA94 |accessdate= 26 February 2011|year=1882|publisher=Lyttelton Times Co.|pages=94–}}</ref> While the Ōhinetahi Homestead is considered to be a significant historic building in the small settlement of Governors Bay,<ref name="Wilson2009">{{cite web |url= http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/canterbury-places/12|title=Canterbury places – Lyttelton Harbour |last= Wilson |first= John |date= 2 March 2009 |work= teara.govt.nz |publisher= Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> the formal garden of Ōhinetahi is considered to be one of New Zealand's finest.<ref name="Mackay2009">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/city-breaks/news/article.cfm?c_id=633&objectid=10558403|title=Christchurch: Take a blooming lovely tour |last=Mackay|first=Janetta |date=25 February 2009|publisher=New Zealand Herald|accessdate=26 February 2011}}</ref> Amongst the early owners of Ōhinetahi were Canterbury pioneer [[William Sefton Moorhouse]] and [[Thomas Potts]], New Zealand's first conservationist. Sir [[Miles Warren]], architect of the [[Christchurch Town Hall]], was the last private owner, and gifted it to New Zealand.<ref name=Vine2009/><ref name="Listener2012" />
==Etymology== The place was once a heavily fortified [[Kāti Māmoe|Ngāti Māmoe]] [[Pā (Māori)|pā]]. Approximately 300 years ago, it was overtaken by Te Rakiwhakaputa of [[Ngāi Tahu]]. After the pā's capture, Manuhiri, son of Te Rakiwhakaputa, resided here, fathering many sons and one daughter after whom the pā is named.<ref name="christchurchcitylibraries.com" />
==History== [[File:Ohinetahi, 1867.jpg|thumb|left|Ohinetahi in 1867 while owned by [[Thomas Potts]]]]
===Establishment and early owners=== The first European owner of the land was Christopher Alderson Calvert (1811–1883), a lawyer practicing in Lyttelton and Christchurch who purchased the land in 1852.<ref name=WarrenP9>Warren, page 9.</ref> He had a one-room cottage designed by Benjamin J. Mountfort and built in Lyttelton before it was transported in sections by boat and carried up to the site.<ref name=WarrenP9/> He named the cottage ''Rosemary Cottage'' after one of [[George Selwyn (Bishop of Lichfield)|Bishop Selwyn]]'s daughters. On consulting local Maori about a name for the property, they suggested and he was delighted to adopt the name, Ohinetahi.<ref name=WarrenP9/> Four subsequent owners followed in a short period of time before William Sefton Moorhouse purchased the property in the mid-1850s. Moorhouse then built a more substantial building either by adding rooms onto each end of the existing cottage or more likely by replacing it with an entirely new house.<ref name=peoplesnetworknz.info/><ref name=WarrenP10>Warren, page 10.</ref> Moorhouse sold the entire 255-acre property to [[Thomas Potts]] in 1858.<ref name=WarrenP10/> Potts proceeded to buy more of the surrounding land until the property covered 572 acres, reaching as far as the seashore at Governors Bay, along the main road as well as Quail island. Between 1863 and 1867 Potts pulled the existing house apart and built a three-story sandstone structure between the two wooden halves.<ref>Warren, page 11.</ref> <ref name=Vine2009>{{cite news|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/lifestyle/travel/76751/architect-set-loose-garden?slide=3|title=Architect set loose in garden |last=Vine |first= Gillian |date= 6 October 2009 |work=odt.co.nz |publisher= Otago Daily Times |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref>
Potts, one of New Zealand's earliest conservationists, established in 1865 a large garden on the property which as well as a vegetable garden and orchard included trees such as araucarias, ashes, blue gums, Lombardy poplars, New World conifers, oaks, sycamores and walnuts.<ref>Warren, page 14.</ref><ref name="gardenstovisit.co.nz">{{cite web |url= http://www.gardenstovisit.co.nz/garden.aspx?gardenid=40 |title= Ohinetahi |year=2010|publisher=Gardens to Visit |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> <ref name="sisley.co.uk" /> The variety of exotic trees and shrubs that Potts selected were on the advice of a friend at [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Kew Garden]].<ref name=peoplesnetworknz.info>{{cite web |url= http://chchkete.peoplesnetworknz.info/site/topics/show/22-ohinetahi |title= Topic: Ohinetahi |date=28 April 2008 |work= peoplesnetworknz.info |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> Pott's four hectare garden included a quince and variegated elm that still survive.<ref name=Vine2009/> After his death in 1888, the garden was left untended until it was mostly just a lawn around the house.
The 572-acre property was then sold in 1896 to William Cook, who sold off several acres and the property was once again subdivided when Cook died with a Mr Beckett and a Mr Stewart buying the property which contained the house. They, in turn, sold off parts until in 1946 the house and the surrounding 9 acres was purchased by Basil Quaife. Quaife subsequently sold this property in 1952 to Herbert Ensor.<ref>Warren, page 14.</ref>
===Miles Warren, John and Pauline Trengrove=== Deciding in the mid-1970s that they would like to create a large garden together John and Pauline Trengrove and Pauline's brother Miles Warren began looking for a suitable site. After a number of setbacks, Miles Warren heard that Ohinetahi was for sale by its current owners Mr and Mrs Herbert Ensor, who would be remaining on an adjacent property. They subsequently bought it for $100,000, financing the purchase by selling other properties. During the period between purchase and possession, the three new owners embarked on a six-week tour of gardens in England in a search for ideas to include in their proposed garden. Among the gardens visited were Sissinghurst, Wilton House and Hidcote Manor. First they restored the large stone colonial villa.<ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite news |url= http://travel.usatoday.com/destinations/guide/Christchurch+and+Canterbury/Sights/47047|title= Ohinetahi |publisher= [[USA Today]] Travel |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> Work commenced on creating the present garden in 1977.
After about ten years John and Pauline decided to build a new house and create a garden on 10 acres of land at Ohoka. To fund their new project Warren purchased their share of the property to become Ohinetahi's sole owner.<ref>Warren, page 92.</ref>
In subsequent years two small art galleries, as well as a cottage for the housekeeper, were constructed on the property. One gallery contains works by prominent New Zealand artists including Shane Cotton, Julian Dashper, Pat Hanly, Ralph Hotere, Richard McWhannell and Peter Robinson. The other gallery contains 3D models and architectural photographs building projects undertaken by the architectural firm of Warren & Mahoney.
The main house was badly damaged by the [[2010 Canterbury earthquake|4 September 2010 Christchurch earthquake]]<ref name= "NZHerald2010">{{cite news|url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10671386 |title= Historic buildings need expert help|date= 6 September 2010|publisher= [[New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> The stone walls of the three storey block were badly cracked and the four gables fell. As a result, it was decided to reduce the central block of the house from three to two stories, while at the same time the house was earthquake strengthened and given a strengthened masonry ground floor and a new timber-framed first floor. While the structure of the art gallery was undamaged the Oamaru stone exterior was badly cracked and had to be rebuilt, only to then be damaged again by the February 2011 earthquake.<ref>Warren, pages 110 to 117.</ref>
After Mrs Esnor died in 2008 Warren was able to purchase from her heirs a 0.76-hectare strip of land which allowed Ohinetahi to be expanded towards the harbour side.<ref>Warren, page 125.</ref> Terraces were constructed on this land using stone removed from the upper storey of the house when it was restored after the earthquake.
In recent times a number of large modern sculptures by renowned New Zealand artists have been installed in both the park and garden.
The housekeeper's cottage has been converted to a tearoom.
In 2012 Miles Warren gifted the homestead and gardens as well as an endowment to the Ohinetahi Charitable Trust to ensure that the property and its contents are preserved for the benefit of the public.<ref name="Listener2012">{{cite journal|last=MacFie|first=Rebecca|title=The Constant Gardener|journal=Listener|date=15 December 2012|volume=236|issue=3788|pages=22–26}}</ref> In early February 2017 a major [[2017 Port Hills fires|fire]] on the Ports Hills which required the excavation of 107 local residents came within 300 to 400 metres of the house coating the property with falling ash.<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |title= Christchurch fire nears Ohinetahi homestead, Sir Miles Warren refuses to leave | publisher= Stuff |date= 16 February 2017 |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11801689 |accessdate= 16 February 2018 }}</ref>
==Structure== The woodland <ref name="Mackay2009"/> that surrounds the home is well structured and designed with views down to the harbour.<ref name=sisley.co.uk>{{cite web |url= http://www.sisley.co.uk/ohinetahi.shtml |title= Ohinetahi |publisher= Sisley Garden Tours |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> Ōhinetahi uses the concept of "rooms" to create effect.<ref name= "bestgardening.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.bestgardening.com/bgc/gardenopen/gardenohinetahi01.htm |title= Ohinetahi Governor's Bay, Canterbury |date= 17 February 2009 |work= bestgardening.com |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> The terraced garden is sectioned into groupings. Hedges shelter those plants that have difficulty in high winds. The garden is characterised by a herb [[potager]], box-edged rose garden, and herbaceous borders. Other features of the English-inspired<ref name="Rewi2010">{{cite book |last= Rewi |first= Adrienne |title= Frommer's New Zealand |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=3xiBJl96cucC&pg=PA10 |accessdate= 26 February 2011 |date= 15 February 2010 |publisher= Frommer's |isbn= 978-0-470-49733-3|pages=10–}}</ref> landscaping include a Red Garden (formerly white), ogee gazebo, pond, bridge, statues,<ref name="gardenvisit.com">{{cite web |url= http://www.gardenvisit.com/garden/ohinetahi |title= Ohinetahi, Gardenvisit Editorial |date= 31 December 2008|work=gardenvisit.com |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> stone and metal sculpture,<ref name="chsgardens.co.nz">{{cite web|url= http://chsgardens.co.nz/about/open-gardens/ohinetahi/ |title= Ohinetahi|publisher=Canterbury Horticultural Society |accessdate= 26 February 2011}}</ref> and an [[Oamaru]] stonewall. The central lawn fronts the house's main façade, which has arched colonial verandas.<ref name="bestgardening.com" /> A stream flows from the garden down to the harbour.<ref name="gardenstovisit.co.nz" />
==Flora== Flora include [[Robinia pseudoacacia|Black Locust]] shade trees, a hedge of [[Cupressus macrocarpa|Monterey Cypress]],<ref name=sisley.co.uk/> as well as densely planted [[rhododendron]]s, [[camellia]]s, and ''[[Buxus]]''.<ref name="gardenstovisit.co.nz" /> Though Potts introduced grasses, he found the [[Poa]] to be hard to eradicate.<ref name="Zealand1877">{{cite book |author= Royal Society of New Zealand|title= Transactions |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=OwI1AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA501 |accessdate= 26 February 2011 |year= 1877 |pages= 501–}}</ref>
==Awards== Ohinetahi has received the Garden of Distinction and Garden of Excellence Award.<ref name="chsgardens.co.nz" /> The homestead is registered as a Category I heritage building with the [[New Zealand Historic Places Trust]].<ref name="NZHPT Ohinetahi">{{NZHPT|3349|Ohinetahi |20 August 2011}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}

'''''Paroikoi''''' (plural of Greek πάροικος, ''paroikos'', the etymological origin of [[:wiktionary:parish|parish]] and [[parochial]]) is the term that replaced "[[metic]]" in the [[Hellenistic]] and Roman period to designate foreign residents.<ref>Encyclopedia of ancient Greece By Nigel Guy Wilson [https://books.google.com/books?id=-aFtPdh6-2QC&pg=PA470 Page 470] {{ISBN|978-0-415-97334-2}} (2006)</ref> In [[Asia Minor]] they were named ''katoikoi''. In the [[Byzantine Empire]], ''paroikoi'' were non-proprietary peasants, hereditary holders of their land, irremovable as long as they paid their rent.<ref>Encyclopedia of the Middle Ages, Part 114, Volume 1 By Adrian Walford Page 1091 </ref> They appeared in the [[Justinian code]], which prohibited this status; so it remained provisionally clandestine.

{{Underlinked|date=May 2014}}
{{Infobox library | library_name = CRAI Biblioteca Pavelló de la República | image = Pavelló general.jpg | location = [[Barcelona]] | coordinates = 41°25'50.6"N 2°09'03.9"E | established = 1996 | num_branches = History | collection_size = Over than 105,000 copies among books and pamphlets compose the library's collection. In the newspapers archive there are 10,000 titles and the archive have over 537 lineal meters. | pop_served = The library is open to everybody | website = [http://www.bib.ub.edu/en/libraries/pavello-republica CRAI Biblioteca Pavelló de la República] }} The Pavelló de la República Library joined what is now the UB’s Learning and Research Resources Centre (CRAI) in 1996. It has since grown to become one of the world’s leading archival libraries on subjects such as the Second Spanish Republic, the [[Spanish Civil War]], exile, the Franco regime and Spain’s transition to democracy. In addition, the library has important materials on the Soviet Bloc and on the international political history of the twentieth history, particularly the [[World War II]].
== Context == [[File:Pabelló República.png|thumb|left|Ubication of the building in Paris]] In 1937, during the Spanish Civil War, the government of the Republic participated in the Exposition Internationale des Arts et Techniques dans la vie moderne, popularly known as the Paris International Exhibition of 1937. The civil war in Spain was experiencing a change in project conception, incialment even more excitement to the technical developments in different countries, and the Spanish Pavilion becomes an evidence of the tragic political situation country: "the character that owes tener the spanish Section of the Exhibition (...) can and should be accounted the present moment and the wonderful village esfuerzo spanish defender for its independence and the cause of peace in the world."
The exhibition lasted from 25 May until 25 November 1937. The Pavilion was opened but not until July 12. Was located at Avenida del Trocadero near the pavilions of Germany and the Soviet Union.
The project architect was the philosopher Jose Gaos, curator of the flag, the painter Josep Renau and writer Max Aub who organized the contents of the exhibition pavilion and commissioned the construction of the building to [[Josep Maria Sert]] and [[Luis Lacasa]].
Audiovisual production was by [[Luis Buñuel]], appointed coordinator of the Propaganda the Information Service at the Embassy in Paris.
== The building == The building of the Pavilion of the Republic, was conceived by its architect Josep Lluis Sert and Luis Lacasa as an empty container, almost three floors and walls. He left the floor open courtyard that communicated with, covered with a tarp, was the role of audience.
On the first floor, devoted to propaganda and information on the situation of the country at war, it was accessed by a stairway and the second aimed at the arts and popular sections, where the large mural by Joan Miró , the Catalan peasant (now disappeared), it was accessed by a ramp, although there was a vertical access to the interior of the structure.
It was built with a limitation of time and materials, many prefabricated panels and plywood, or synthetic, and adapting the plan to build an irregular terrain, slope and with the obligation to respect the trees in allocated land. It had an area of 1,400 square meters.
It took a sober building that followed the lines of rational architecture despite its ephemeral nature. So basically acquired a cultural and propaganda to let the world know the situation unfolding in Spain, precisely define the objectives of government and emphasized the heroic struggle of the Spanish people.
Inside (front and acting as a gigantic panel exhibitor), they exhibited posters, photographs, photomontages, proclamations, information panels, as well as art and craft, sent directly from Spanish central and regional governments and various unions. Much of the exhibits sought to proclaim to the public the situation was before and after the Spanish Republic, and the war situation.
One of its main attractions was the famous Guernica by Pablo Picasso, located in one wall of the central courtyard where the Mercury Fountain, made by Alexander Calder.
=== The building now === [[File:Pavelló escales.JPG|thumb|Main entrance]] With the Olympic Games of 1992, the City Council commended the architects Antonio Ubach, Juan Miguel Hernandez and Miguel Espinet Leon carrying a replica of the Pavilion of the Republic that had been presented at the International Exhibition of Paris of 1937 and was destroyed in the end.
Today, this landmark building, given since 1994, the City Council at the University of Barcelona, is occupied by CRAI Library Hall of the Republic, which has one of the most important collection in the world on Second Republic Civil War, Francoism, Transition and exile in Spain, especially in Catalonia and the International Centre for Historical Studies, founded by Jaume Vicens Vives.
A reproduction of Picasso's famous Guernica can be seen, as was its original location, on a wall of the open courtyard of the pavilion.
== Equipment == *Area: 1.109 m2 *Restricted bookcases: 5.294 metres lineals *Reading points: 42 (Reading room: 30 / Basement: 12) *Self-service photocopier: 1 *Searching PC's: 3 *VHS/DVD player: 1
== Specific services ==
*Access conditions and fund's search *Reproduction and document's for borrowing *Building use *Pavelló de la República video *Library's catalogue's news *Visits to the Pavelló e la República *Building plan *Training *Pavelló de la República's fund diffusion *Library's annual report

{{redirect-distinguish|Wrestling in Australia|Amateur wrestling in Australia}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} '''[[Professional wrestling]] in [[Australia]]''' makes up a small part of Australian [[culture]]. Unlike the [[North America]]n or [[Japan]]ese products which have large, globally renowned organisations such as [[World Wrestling Entertainment]], [[New Japan Pro Wrestling]] or [[Impact Wrestling]] with several hundred smaller [[professional wrestling promotion|promotions]], Australia only has approximately 30 smaller [[independent circuit]] promotions which exist in all but one of the states and territories, that being the [[Northern Territory]]. Tours from the North American product are regularly sold out in capital cities such as [[Melbourne]], [[Sydney]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] and [[Brisbane]].
==History== Professional wrestling in Australia first gained distinction in the early 1900s, however there were very few shows promoted. Nonetheless, stars such as [[Clarence Weber]], [[Jack Carkeek]], [[Clarence Whistler]] and [[Georg Hackenschmidt]] toured the country. As time went on, the sport's popularity began to grow, particularly in the 1930s as people sought to find relief from [[Great Depression|The Great Depression]].
Throughout the 1940s professional wrestling suffered due to [[World War II]] but in the 1950s it reached new highs as many stars from overseas were imported and created larger crowds and, in turn, a larger market. Established names such as [[Lou Thesz]], [[Dr. Jerry Graham]] and [[Gorgeous George]] toured the country during the decade.
Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Australia established its only major [[professional wrestling promotion|promotion]] in [[WCW Australia]]. WCW had a television deal with the [[Nine Network]], the first in Australia to do so and attracted crowds between 2,000 and 9,000 people on a weekly basis. International stars such as [[Killer Kowalski]], [[Ray Stevens (wrestler)|Ray Stevens]], [[Dominic Denucci]], [[Mario Milano]], [[Spiros Arion]], [[Karl Gotch]], [[Bruno Sammartino]], [[Gorilla Monsoon]] and local stars Ron Miller and [[Larry O'Dea]] were all involved with the promotion which grew steadily through the 1960s and was a well known product in the 1970s. However, with the introduction of [[World Series Cricket]], WCW was left with no television deal and was forced to close down in 1978. This sent the Australian market into a large decline. With no access to any product anywhere in the world, the Australian market was almost dead until the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] became a prominent figure in professional wrestling in the mid-1980s.
Australia has depended on the [[North America]]n product since 1985. Hosting tours in 1985 and 1986 kept a solid viewing in the sport through programmes such as ''Superstars of Wrestling'' and ''Saturday Night's Main Event''. Small local promotions have tried to take advantage of the popularity of professional wrestling in more recent times, but there has been nothing of note since the demise of World Championship Wrestling in 1978.
However the local scene has been the subject of controversy.
In September 2002, a promotion called PCW presented a show called ''Carnage'', in which two wrestlers faced off in the first-ever barbed-wire match in [[Australia]]. The event was billed as a "Great Family Night Out", however before the bout an announcer warned parents to take their children from the Rowville arena if they were upset by blood.<ref>From the video of the event - now a collector's item.</ref>
The match saw real blood, fake glass and one contestant setting fire to a chair. The ring ropes were replaced with barbed wire and a bucket of thumb tacks was dumped on the ring floor. Much of the controversy surrounded rumours about the event, suggesting that the outpour of blood was so intense that it 'splattered' onto members of the crowd. Much of this can be attributed to people who had heard about the match giving their take of it on the Internet.
Despite the fact that this event was publicised as having a gory match and the preceding warning, people complained that the match in question was 'too much'. A concerned mother called Melbourne Talkback radio station [[3AW]], and a wrestler heard this call and also rang in. This resulted in the main media outlets covering the story. For the record, neither of the wrestlers were seriously injured.<ref>Television coverage by the [[Nine Network]] at the time.</ref> It also resulted in a police investigation.<ref>[[The Age|Melbourne Age]] newspaper 12 September 2002.</ref> and a furore within the local [[Knox City Council]].<ref>Melbourne [[Herald Sun]] newspaper</ref>
==Australian wrestlers overseas== Individual wrestlers originating in [[Australia]] have struggled for the most part to obtain any international recognition. Perhaps the two biggest names when one mentions Australia are the Fabulous Kangaroos - [[Roy Heffernan]] and [[Al Costello]]. They are the only Australian wrestlers to [[celebrity|make it big]] in the [[United States]] and held the [[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Florida version)|Florida]] and [[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Texas version)|Texas]] versions of the NWA World Tag Team titles as well as the [[WWWF United States Tag Team Championship|north east version]] of the NWA United States tag team titles in the Capitol Wrestling Corporation (later to become [[WWE]])<ref>{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan & Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|year=2006|edition=4th|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref> on three occasions, as well as being inducted into the [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwi-online.com/pages/hallofame.html|title=Wrestling Observer Hall of Fame|website=www.pwi-online.com}}</ref>
Australian wrestler [[Peter Stilsbury]] was brought into the WWF in the mid-1980s under the name Outback Jack in response to the mainstream popularity at the time of the Australian film ''[["Crocodile" Dundee|Crocodile Dundee]]''.<ref>{{cite book|pages=339–340|publisher=ECW Press|year=2007|first=R.D.|last=Reynolds|author2=Blade Braxton |isbn=1-55022-762-9|title=The Wrestlecrap Book of Lists!}}</ref> He appeared in several vignettes hyping his debut by showing Jack in the wilds of the Australian Outback, drinking beer with cows,<ref name=wcrp>{{cite book|page=34|first=R.D.|last=Reynolds|title=WrestleCrap: The Very Worst of Pro Wrestling|publisher=ECW Press|year=2003|isbn=1-55022-584-7}}</ref> and came down to the ring to the theme song by [[Rolf Harris]], "Tie Me Kangaroo Down, Sport".<ref>{{cite episode|series=WWF Television|title=WWF Superstars of Wrestling|episodelink=WWF Superstars of Wrestling|network=[[Broadcast syndication|Syndicated]]|location=[[Tampa, Florida]]|airdate=7 February 1987}}</ref> Outback Jack started his career touring in [[Canada]] with Stu Hart's Stampede Wrestling.
In more recent times [[Nathan Jones (wrestler)|Nathan Jones]] made two WWE appearances in 2003 at [[WrestleMania XIX]]<ref>Jones was originally meant to team with [[The Undertaker]] but was ([[kayfabe]]) beaten down by their opponents before the match. Jones appeared later in the match.</ref> and at [[Survivor Series (2003)|Survivor Series]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/2003/results/|title=Home|publisher=}}</ref> later that same year even though he only actually wrestled at the latter event, making him the first Australian wrestler to ever perform on a WWE [[pay-per-view]] event. Jones also performed on two [[World Wrestling All-Stars]] pay-per-views, losing to [[Jeff Jarrett]] at [[List of WWA pay-per-view events#The Inception|WWA: The Inception]] and to [[Scott Steiner]] at [[List of WWA pay-per-view events#The Eruption|WWA: The Eruption]].<ref name="Eruption source">{{cite web|url=http://www.lordsofpain.net/news/2002/articles/1018738939.php|title=WWA The Eruption results|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926230554/http://www.lordsofpain.net/news/2002/articles/1018738939.php|archivedate=26 September 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In late 2011, [[WWE]] signed an Australian female wrestler [[Emma (wrestler)|Tenille Dashwood]] to its development territory [[NXT (WWE brand)|NXT]]. She was originally from [[Melbourne]]. Dashwood debuted as a clumsy dancer Emma, and in early 2014 was elevated to the main roster. On 6 April 2014 she became only the second Australian wrestler to perform on a WWE pay per view and the first ever woman to do so when she was a part of the Diva's Title match at [[WrestleMania XXX]]. She later appeared at the 2014 [[Survivor Series]] in November. In 2017 she became the first Australian to perform at three WWE pay per view events when she was part of the fatal five way for the [[Raw Women's Championship]] at [[No Mercy (2017)|No Mercy]]. She made it four at [[TLC (2017)|TLC]] in opposition to [[Asuka (wrestler)|Asuka]].
In early 2013, WWE signed another Australian wrestler [[Buddy Murphy]], known in Australia as Matt Silva to [[NXT (WWE brand)|NXT]]. Murphy made his televised debut on NXT 15 May 2014, teaming with Elias Samson in a losing effort against The Ascension.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wwenxt/2014-05-15/results-26304217|title=WWE NXT: May 15, 2014|publisher=}}</ref> In August 2014, Murphy began teaming with American Wesley Blake and in January 2015, Murphy and Blake scored an upset victory over the Vaudevillains and the following week defeated the [[Lucha Dragons]] to win the [[NXT Tag Team Championship]], making Murphy the first Australian to hold a championship within the WWE.<ref name=spoilernxttag>{{cite web|title=NXT News: Next live special announced, full spoiler results from Thursday's NXT TV tapings|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_82772.shtml|website=PWTorch.com|accessdate=16 January 2015}}</ref> In early 2018 Murphy joined the Cruiserweight division and participated in the Cruiserweight title tournament losing to [[Mustafa Ali]] in the quarter finals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/shows/wwe-205-live/2018-03-06/article/mustafa-ali-def-buddy-murphy|title=Mustafa Ali def. Buddy Murphy|publisher=}}</ref> He soon become a top contender to the new champion [[Cedric Alexander]], and he managed to defeat Alexander at [[WWE Super Show-Down]] in his main roster pay-per-view debut in his home town [[Melbourne, Victoria|Melbourne]] to win the [[WWE Cruiserweight Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/shows/wwe-super-show-down/2018-10-06/cedric-alexander-buddy-murphy-results|title=Buddy Murphy lays claim to the WWE Cruiserweight Championship|publisher=}}</ref>
In April 2015, WWE signed both [[Billie Kay]] and [[Peyton Royce]] to NXT.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/shows/wwenxt/wwe-performance-center-welcomes-new-class-of-recruits|title=WWE Performance Center welcomes new class of recruits|publisher=}}</ref> The pair later formed the team [[The IIconics]] under their original name of The Iconic Duo.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/shows/wwenxt/article/iconic-duo-campaign-nxt-year-end-awards-2017-votes?sf179037009=1|title=The Iconic Duo hit the campaign trail in search of NXT Year-End Award votes|publisher=}}</ref>. They were elevated to the main roster on the SmackDown brand just after [[WrestleMania 34]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/videos/billie-kay-and-peyton-royce-attack-charlotte-flair-smackdown-live-april-10-2018|title=NXT's Billie Kay and Peyton Royce make their debut by attacking SmackDown Women's Champion Charlotte Flair|publisher=}}</ref> and made their main roster pay per view debut at [[WWE Super Show-Down]] with a victory over the team of [[Asuka (wrestler)|Asuka]] and [[Naomi (wrestler)|Naomi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wwe.com/shows/wwe-super-show-down/2018-10-06/asuka-naomi-the-iiconics-results|title=The IIconics battle Asuka & Naomi in homecoming clash|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Rhea Ripley]] joined WWE and participated in the [[Mae Young Classic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.news.com.au/sport/more-sports/rhea-ripley-is-chasing-dreams-in-the-wwe/news-story/270342aea181dc22286f10480119f063|title=Meet Australia’s next WWE star|publisher=}}</ref> The Adelaide based wrestler known locally as Demi Bennett would go on to participate in the second Mae Young Classic in 2018, but at TV tapings in [[Birmingham, England]] Ripley became the first Australian woman to win a WWE controlled title when she defeated fellow Australian [[Toni Storm]] in a tournament final to be the inaugural winner of the WWE UK Women's Championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.f4wonline.com/wwe-news/wwe-crowns-first-nxt-uk-womens-champion-tv-tapings-264651|title=WWE crowns first NXT UK Women's Champion at TV tapings|date=26 August 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
Only two other Australian wrestlers have appeared on a worldwide pay-per-view event to date at all. They are Chuck E. Chaos at ''[[List of WWA pay-per-view events#The Eruption|WWA: The Eruption]]''<ref name="Eruption source"/> who lost to [[Jerry Lynn]], and [[Mark Mercedes]] at [[List of WWA pay-per-view events#The Reckoning|WWA: The Reckoning]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lordsofpain.net/news/2003/articles/1053920249.php|title=WWA The Reckoning results|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929095657/http://www.lordsofpain.net/news/2003/articles/1053920249.php|archivedate=29 September 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> who lost to [[Rick Steiner]].
==Foreign tours== [[File:Triple H Entrance Sequence Melbourne 10.11.2007.jpg|thumb|450px|right|Sequence showing [[Triple H]] performing his ring entrance pose at the [[Rod Laver Arena]] in [[Melbourne]] during the November 2007 [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] tour]]
Shows from North American promotions have been held in Australia as early as 1985 when WWE toured through [[Melbourne]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]] and through Melbourne and Brisbane again in 1986. That was the last Australia saw of a live North American product until [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]] did a ''[[WCW Monday Nitro|Nitro]]'' and ''[[WCW Thunder|Thunder]]'' taping in Melbourne,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling.net.au/articles/pages/aussie/article54.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030913231435/http://www.wrestling.net.au/articles/pages/aussie/article54.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2003-09-13|title="TV Nitro to hit town"|publisher=}}</ref> a ''[[WCW Monday Nitro|Nitro]]'' taping in Brisbane and a ''[[WCW Thunder|Thunder]]'' taping and a house show in Sydney in 2000.
The next time WWE came to Australia was for the ''WWE Global Warning Tour'' in 2002 for what was the first WWE event in Australia in 16 years. The tour drew 56,734 people in [[Docklands Stadium]], Melbourne; it featured nine matches, where in the main event [[Dwayne Johnson|The Rock]] defeated [[Triple H]] and [[Brock Lesnar]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|Triple Threat match]] to retain the [[WWE Championship|WWE Undisputed Championship]]. ''Global Warning'' did not air on [[pay-per-view]], but was released on home video. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/118-daily-updates/42664-thurs-update-more-from-nxt-takeover-samoa-joe-deal-notes-what-tna-talent-has-been-told-white-predicts-2-million-buys-for-rousey-vs-cyborg-lawler-angle-|title=THURS. In October 2018, Global Warning was added to the on demand list on [[WWE Network]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pwinsider.com/article/120741/wwe-network-adds-previous-australian-stadium-event.html?p=1|title=WWE NETWORK ADDS PREVIOUS AUSTRALIAN STADIUM EVENT - PWInsider.com|website=pwinsider.com}}</ref>

In 2000, [[I-Generation Superstars of Wrestling]] held a pay-per-view in Sydney headlined "Rodman Down Under" where Dennis Rodman would lose to [[Curt Hennig]] with the i-Generation Championship being contested.

In 2016, [[House of Hardcore]] presented House Of Hardcore 15 in Melbourne. Various smaller shows have featured overseas talent, but nothing else of note.

==Television programming==
===History=== Throughout the 1990s, both ''[[WCW Monday Nitro]]'' and ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'' were broadcast pay television networks with [[WCW Monday Nitro]] on TNT and [[WWE Raw]] on Fox Sports . WWE's major [[pay-per-view]]s [[Royal Rumble]], [[WrestleMania]], [[King of the Ring]], [[SummerSlam]] and [[Survivor Series]] began to be shown on pay-per-view by the late 1990s.
In September 2002 negotiations between [[FOX8]] and WWE fell through and ''SmackDown!'' was cancelled. A special [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|NWA-TNA]] package replaced it in early 2003 but only lasted a year. NWA-TNA pay-per-views were shown once a month throughout 2003 during a time when they were being presented weekly in the [[United States]]. WWE pay-per-views were also lost to [[Main Event]] in the same deal that cost Australian fans SmackDown. [[Village Roadshow|Village Cinemas]] showed them for a few months until August 2003 when ''SmackDown!'' returned on Saturday nights as well as the pay-per-views, starting with [[SummerSlam]]. ''RAW'' was moved from [[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]] to FOX8 and was shown on Friday nights. In order to prevent spoiler hunting on the internet, FOX8 moved WWE programming to timeslots closer to their United States air date.
In February 2005, ''[[WWE Heat]]'', ''[[WWE Velocity]]'' and ''[[The WWE Experience]]'' were added to Fox8 and set up a large wrestling program on Saturdays and Sundays. Despite ''Heat'', ''Velocity'' and ''Experience'' all being cancelled in the [[United States]] the shows continued to be shown in Australia to fulfill contractual obligations. When ''SmackDown!'' was moved to Friday nights in the United States, in Australia it remained on Friday afternoons. ''[[ECW on Syfy|ECW on Sci Fi]] '' began broadcasting in Australia from 2 September 2006 in the place of ''[[WWE Velocity]]'' on Saturdays and the [[WWE Fanatic Series]] began airing in October 2006.
RAW has been airing in Australia on [[Fox8]] since late 2003 on tape delay. But it start airing RAW live on 4 February 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2014/01/wwe-raw-goes-live-on-fox8.html|title=WWE Raw goes Live on FOX8|publisher=tvtonight.com.au|date=2014-01-23|accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref>
After just over 3 years, TNA made its return. Beginning with ''[[TNA Sacrifice#2006|TNA Sacrifice 2006]]'' on 27 May 2006 on tape delay. This continued for 12 months before events started being broadcast live in May 2007. ''[[TNA Impact!]]'' began airing on 5 April 2008 on [[Fox8]]. [[TNA Impact]] had been airing on Saturday nights on [[Fuel TV (Australia)|Fuel TV]] at 8.30pm AEST from June 2011, but this ceased in November 2014 when Fuel was absorbed by Fox Sports. For the remainder of 2014 and into 2015 it was shown on Main Event free of the usual charges, until 27 June 2015.<ref name="mainevent.com.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.mainevent.com.au/news/239/tna-final-episode-airs-on-main-event-27-june-2015.aspx|title=TNA final episode airs on MAIN EVENT - 27 June 2015 - MAIN EVENT|publisher=}}</ref>
Free to air wrestling programming has been scarce on Australian television in recent times. However, with the conversion to Digital Television, several wrestling programs were purchased. In June 2008, [[WWE After Burn]] aired on Channel 9 on Sunday afternoon. However, it later aired at 1am on Tuesday mornings. [[TNA Xplosion]] began airing on [[One HD]] in prime time at 8:30pm on Thursday but by late 2010 it had been replaced in effect by the WWE Experience.
A cut down, one hour version of WWE Raw and SmackDown Live now air on [[Nine Network]]'s [[9Go!]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/worldwide/article/wwe-nine-network-broadcast-agreement-announcement|title=WWE, Nine Network reach broadcast agreement|publisher=}}</ref>

Any pay-per-views that are upcoming are listed on the Main Event article.--> <!--Please do not specify a date for the commencement of WWF/E and/or WCW pay per views without a verifiable source--> [[Pay-per-view]]s in Australia are shown on [[Main Event]], the only provider in Australia. Main Event has been broadcasting pay-per-views for both [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] starting from the late 1990s until the present time (including the Fanatic Series from 2006) and [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]] pay-per-views from around the same time until they were bought out in March 2001. Main Event also began broadcasting [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|TNA]] pay-per-views in May 2006, starting with [[TNA Sacrifice#2006|Sacrifice]]. One year later, TNA pay per views were lifted from the 13-day tape delay format to a live format. This ceased after the transmission of [[Slammiversary (2015)|Slammiversary]] on 29 June 2015.<ref name="mainevent.com.au"/>

{{distinguish|Saltire Prize}} The '''Saltire Society Literary Awards''' are made annually by the [[Saltire Society]]. The awards seek to recognise books which are either by "living authors of Scottish descent or residing in Scotland," or which deal with "the work or life of a Scot or with a Scottish question, event or situation."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/awards/ |title=Awards |publisher=Saltire Society |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> The awards have been described as "the premiere prize for writing by Scots or about Scotland."<ref>{{cite news|title=Welsh a surprise contender for Saltire Awards |first=Susan |last=Mansfield |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/welsh-a-surprise-contender-for-saltire-awards-1-627949|newspaper=The Scotsman|date=6 November 2002 |accessdate=18 December 2016}}</ref>
The first Saltire Society Book Award was given in 1937, the year after the Saltire Society was established. No awards were given after 1939 due to the Second World War, and the next award was made 1956. The History Book of the Year award was inaugurated in 1965. In 1982 sponsorship was obtained and since then the awards have been made annually. First books have been recognised since 1988, and in 1998 the award for Scottish Research Book of the Year was established.<ref name=25yrs>{{cite web |url=http://www.scottisharts.org.uk/1/artsinscotland/literature/projects/archive/saltiresocietyawards.aspx |title=The Saltire Society Book of the Year Awards: A celebration of twenty five years of literature |publisher=Scottish Arts Council |accessdate=22 January 2014}}</ref> The Saltire Society currently presents awards in the four following categories:<ref name=boty/>
* '''Scottish Book of the Year''' * '''Scottish First Book of the Year''' * '''Scottish History Book of the Year''' * '''Scottish Research Book of the Year'''
In addition, an annual student travel bursary is awarded to a [[creative writing]] graduate, and the Ross Roy Medal is awarded for the best [[PhD]] thesis on a subject related to Scottish literature.<ref name=boty>{{cite web |url=http://www.saltiresociety.org.uk/news/2013/11/15/scottish-book-of-the-year-winner-announced |title=Scottish Book of the Year Winner Announced |publisher=Saltire Society |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> A one-off Homecoming Book of the Year award was made in 2009 to celebrate the "[[Homecoming Scotland 2009|Year of Homecoming]]": the award was presented to American professor [[Donald Worster]] for his biography of [[John Muir]], ''A Passion for Nature''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.booksfromscotland.com/Books/Award-Winning-Scottish-Books/Saltire-Society-Literary-Awards |title=Saltire Society Literary Awards - Winning Books |publisher=Books from Scotland |accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref>

The '''Scottish Place-Name Society''' (''Comann Ainmean-Áite na h-Alba'' in [[Scottish Gaelic language|Gaelic]]) is a [[learned society]] in [[Scotland]] concerned with [[toponymy]], the study of place-names. Its scholars aim to explain the origin and history of the place-names they study, taking into account the meaning of the elements out of which they were created; the topography, geology and ecology of the places bearing the names; and the general and local history and culture of Scotland.
The Society was founded in February 1996. The Society's journal, ''The Journal of Scottish Name Studies'' (''JSNS''), has been published since 2007.

{{Infobox Museum |image= Logo_SNM.jpg |name= Slovak National Museum |native_name = Slovenské národné múzeum |native_name_lang = Hungaruab |established= {{Start date|1961}} |location= [[Slovakia]] |architect = M. M. Harminec |director= Rastislav Púdelka |website= {{URL|http://www.snm.sk|Museum website}} |collection= 3,894,000 }} The '''Slovak National Museum''' ({{lang-sk|Slovenské národné múzeum}}) is the most important institution focusing on [[scientific research]] and cultural [[education]] in the field of [[museology]] in [[Slovakia]]. Its beginnings "are connected with the endeavour of the [[Slovaks|Slovak nation]] for national emancipation and self-determination".{{cite web | publisher = City of Bratislava | url = http://www.snm.sk/?lang=eng&org=0§ion=home&show | title = Slovak national museum - Museum | date = n.d. |accessdate = April 30, 2007}} It is headquartered in [[Bratislava]], however, the Slovak National Museum governs 18 specialized museums, most of which are located outside the city. ==History== The Slovak National Museum (SNM) was established in 1961. Its origins lie in the [[Matica slovenská|Matica Slovenská]] Museum and the Museum of the National House in [[Martin, Slovakia|Martin]], which developed the Slovak Museology Society. The first permanent exposition funded from a national collection was opened in Martin in 1908. The museum was building [[Archaeology|archaeological]], [[Ethnography|ethnographic]], historical, [[numismatics|numismatic]], art historical, creative art and natural science collections. The Slovak National Geographic and History Museum was established in Bratislava in 1924 by the Slovak National Geographic and History Museum Society. The [[Agriculture|Agricultural]] Museum, a department of the [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]] Agricultural Museum in [[Prague]], was established in Bratislava the same year. In 1940, the Slovak National Geographic and History Museum and the Agricultural Museum were merged into the Slovak Museum. In 1961, the Slovak Museum and the [[Slovak National Museum in Martin]] were merged into the Slovak National Museum, based in Bratislava. On March 11, 2012, the Krásna Hôrka Castle (part of the SNM), was damaged by a fire started when two children were lighting cigarettes.{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2113802/Kosice-Slovakia-Children-burn-14th-century-castle-cigarette.html |title=14th century castle gutted in blaze sparked by two young boys who had sneaked into grounds to smoke their first cigarette |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=12 March 2012 |author=Tom Gardner |accessdate=3 August 2016}} The fire destroyed the roof but most of the historic collections were undamaged. The castle is expected to reopen in 2018.{{cite web |url=http://spectator.sme.sk/c/20056484/burned-krasna-horka-castle-should-open-in-2018.html |title=Burned Krásna Hôrka Castle should open in 2018 |newspaper=The Spectator, Slovakia |date=10 March 2015 |accessdate=3 August 2016}} ==The museum today== [[Image:BA-riverfront-06.jpg|thumb|right|Slovak National Museum building in Bratislava, viewed from the right bank of the [[Danube]]]] The Slovak National Museum is the most important scientific research and cultural education institution, with the largest and best collections in the museological field in Slovakia. The museum is also dedicated to scientific research tasks and [[publishing]] activities. Moreover, the SNM is "a coordination, methodological, professional advisory, statistical, educational and information centre for the whole field of museology in the Slovak Republic." ===Building=== The Slovak National Museum's headquarters are located on Vajanské nábrežie (a river front street in [[Old Town, Bratislava|Bratislava's Old Town]]), along with the Natural History Museum. The construction of the building, designed by architect M. M. Harminec, began in July 1925 and was completed in 1928. The museum opened on May 4, 1930. ==Specialized museums and departments==

{{Infobox museum | name = South-West Brabant Museum | native_name = Zuidwestbrabants Museum | native_name_lang = | image = 20110419 Halle (11).jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Former location at the college of Jesuits house | map_type = Belgium | coordinates = {{coord|50|44|17.431|N|4|14|11.819|E|region:|display=inline,title}} | former_name = | established = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = [[Halle, Belgium]] | type = [[local museum]] | accreditation = | collections = | visitors = | founder = | director = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|example.com}} }} The '''South-West Brabant Museum''' (Dutch: ''Zuidwestbrabants Museum'') is a [[local museum]] in [[Halle, Belgium|Halle]], [[Flemish Brabant]], [[Belgium]]. From 1981 the museum was housed for decades in a former college of [[Society of Jesus|Jesuits]] from the 17th century. After a closure of half a year in 2014, it was reopened in Den Ast.<ref name="Nieuwsblad">Het Nieuwsblad, [https://www.nieuwsblad.be/cnt/dmf20140912_01265187 Hals museum sluit zondagavond de deuren], 13 september 2014 {{nl}}</ref>
== Collections == It maintains and conserves around 20,000 pieces and is centered around archeology,<ref name="ExpCentr">Expertisecentrum voor Technisch, Wetenschappelijk en Industrieel Erfgoed, [http://www.etwie.be/database/actor/zuidwestbrabants-museum Zuidwestbrabants Museum] {{nl}}</ref> music and the local histories of Halle, the [[Pajottenland]], [[Zenne]] and [[Sonian Forest|Sonian]].<ref name="OKV">Openbaar Kunstbezit Vlaanderen, [http://www.tento.be/musea/zuidwestbrabants-museum Zuidwestbrabants Museum] {{nl}}</ref>
For a great part the way of living of humans from earlier times is told. The museum rebuilt a workers home from the 19th century. A detailed look is given at [[weaving]], [[pottery]], [[braid]]ing [[basket]]s, [[city guard]]s, [[forge|forging]] [[noble metal]]s, [[painting]] art, [[glass art]], [[agriculture]], and [[pilgrimage]].<ref name="ExpCentr" /><ref name="OKV" />
Another selection pays attention to local musicians, like cellist [[Adrien-François Servais]] (1807-1866) and various family members, like his musical sons Franz and Joseph, grand daughter [[Misia Sert]] and sons in law [[Ernest Van Dyck]] and [[Cyprien Godebski]].<ref name="OKV" />
In Den Ast it is located at the former establishment of the [[malt house]] Van Roye. The ground floor pays attention to eight hundred years of history of the city, among which the pilgrimage. The first floor is focused on the music culture in the city and [[carnival]]. There is also an experience trail through the old malt house. The exhibited collection is smaller than in the former Jesuits college, however is will be changed every four to five years. There are also digital presentations.<ref name="Nieuwsblad" /><ref name="ExpCentr" />

}} [[File:Cairo Castle GardenTaiz,Yemen.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Cairo Castle]]'s garden]]'''Taiz''' ({{lang-ar|تعز}}, ''Taʿizz'') is a city in southwestern [[Yemen]]. It is located in the Yemeni Highlands, near the port city of [[Mocha, Yemen|Mocha]] on the [[Red Sea]], lying at an elevation of about {{convert|1,400|m}} above sea level. It is the capital of [[Taiz Governorate]]. With a population of over 600,000 in 2005, it is the third largest city in Yemen after the capital [[Sana'a]] and the southern port city of [[Aden]]. Taiz is considered to be the cultural capital of Yemen.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
==History==
In 130 CE the [[Jewish Sharab|Jewish quarter]] was established in the city. One of the famous and most accepted traveler in Taiz was Ibn Battuta. In his travels he describes this city as "one of the most beautiful and extensive cities of Yemen." Ibn was invited to a banquet with the king and received a warm and inviting welcome. <ref>Ibn Battuta, The Travels of Ibn Battuta</ref>
===Islamic era===
Taiz was ruled by [[Turan-Shah]], the older brother of [[Saladin]], after he had conquered Yemen in 1173 CE.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VYRtAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA197|title=A History of Egypt: Volume 6, In the Middle Ages|last=Lane-Poole|first=Stanley|date=2013-10-03|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9781108065696|location=|pages=197|language=en}}</ref> Turan-Shah built the citadel on the hill overlooking the old city.<ref>Steven C. Caton: ''Yemen''. ABC-CLIO, 2013, p.52 </ref> In 1175 CE, Taiz was made the capital of Yemen as it was incorporated into dominions of the [[Ayyubid dynasty]] by Turan-Shah.
The second [[Rasulid]] King, Almaddhafar (1288 CE), established Taiz as the second capital of the Rasulid Dynasty after [[Zabid]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=m2QjCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT305|title=Yemen: The Unknown Arabia|last=Mackintosh-Smith|first=Tim|date=2014-06-03|publisher=The Overlook Press|year=|isbn=9781468309980|location=|pages=305|language=en}}</ref> In 1332 [[Ibn Battutah]] visited Taiz and described it as one of the largest and most beautiful cities of Yemen.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ro--tXw_hxMC&pg=PA626|title=First Encyclopaedia of Islam: 1913-1936|last=|first=|date=1993|publisher=BRILL|year=|isbn=9004097961|location=|pages=626|language=en}}</ref>
In the 1500, the capital is moved to [[Sana'a]] by the ruler of the [[Tahirid dynasty|Taharid dynasty]]. In 1516 Taiz comes under [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] control.
===20th century===
In 1918 the Ottomans lost Taiz to the new [[Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen|independent Yemen]].
Taiz remained a walled city until 1948 when Imam Ahmed made it the second capital of Yemen, allowing for expansion beyond its fortified wall.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4uYpAQAAMAAJ&q=rasulid+ta'izz+OR+taiz&dq=rasulid+ta'izz+OR+taiz&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik_YzIkJbUAhUPOsAKHYpPAUoQ6AEIKDAA|title=The Encyclopaedia of Islam: TAHRIR-TARDJAMA|last=Gibb|first=Hamilton Alexander Rosskeen|date=1998|publisher=Brill|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=118|language=en}}</ref>
In the 1960s, the first purified water system in Yemen is opened in Taiz. In 1962, state administrations move back to Sana'a.
===2011 Yemeni uprising=== During the [[Yemeni Revolution]] [[Battle of Taiz (2011)|fighting]] in Taiz resulted in anti-government forces seizing control of the city from president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]].
As part of the [[Yemeni civil war (2015–present)|2015 Yemeni Civil War]], on 22 March 2015, the [[Houthis]] and forces loyal to former president Ali Abdullah Saleh took the city in the [[Aftermath of the 2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état|aftermath]] of their [[2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état|coup d'état]] in [[Sana'a]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/23/world/middleeast/houthi-rebels-taiz-yemen.html?_r=0|agency=The New York Times|title=Rebels Seize Key Parts of Yemen’s Third-Largest City, Taiz|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> Then the city endured [[Battle of Taiz (2015–2016)|a military confrontation]] between [[Houthis]] and the forces loyal to [[Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi]]. The city was effectively under siege and the [[United Nations]] warned of an "extreme and irreversible" food shortage if fighting continued.<ref>{{cite news|title=UN warns of ‘extreme’ and ‘irreversible’ food shortage in Taiz|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/10/30/un-warns-of-extreme-and-irreversible-food-shortage-in-taiz.html|accessdate=14 November 2015|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|agency=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=30 October 2015}}</ref> In August 2015 Yemeni MP Muhammad Muqbil Al-Himyari reported Houthi attacks on civilians in Taiz and appealed for help on Suhail TV (Yemen).<ref>{{cite web|title=#5060 - Yemeni MP Muhammad Muqbil Al-Himyari Breaks Down in Tears When Discussing Situation in Taiz, Yemen Suhail TV|url=http://www.memritv.org/clip/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5060.htm|website=Memritv|date=August 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Transcript #5060 - Yemeni MP Muhammad Muqbil Al-Himyari Breaks Down in Tears When Discussing Situation in Taiz, Yemen |url=http://www.memritv.org/clip_transcript/en/5060.htm|website=Memritv|date=August 24, 2015}}</ref>
==Geography==
===Climate=== Taiz has a [[Humid subtropical climate]]. The average daily temperature high during August is {{convert|33|C|F}}. Annual rainfall of Taiz is around {{convert|600|mm|in}}, but on Jabal Sabir it is probably around {{convert|1000|mm|in|1}} per year.
{{Weather box |width = auto |location= Taiz |single line = yes |metric first = yes

==Landmarks== {{double image|right|27 Taizz (10) Al-Ashrafiya.jpg|200|200612 Yemen-226 (354283430).jpg|200|[[Ashrafiya Mosque]]|[[Mudhaffar Mosque]]}} The city has many old and beautiful quarters, with houses that are typically built with brown bricks, and [[mosque]]s are usually white. Most famous among the mosques are the [[Ashrafiya Mosque|Ashrafiya]], the [[Muctabiya]] and the [[Mudhaffar Mosque|Mudhaffar]]. Also memorable are the old citadel and the governor's palace that rests on top of a mountain spur 450 metres above the city centre. It also has one of the most famous mountains in Yemen, the Saber mountain (almost 3000 meters above sea level), which affords panoramic views over the city. The city has a Muslim [[madrasa]] that has [[university]] status.
==Economy==
Historically, the mountainous city of Taiz was known for [[coffee production]]. The coffee produced in Taiz was considered some of the finest in the region in the early 20th century.<ref name=Prothero83>{{cite book|last=Prothero|first=G.W.|title=Arabia|year=1920|publisher=H.M. Stationery Office|location=London|page=83|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/11767/view/1/83/}}</ref> Today, coffee remains a major part of the economy but mango, pomegranate, citrus banana, papai, vegetables, cereals, onions, and [[khat|qat]] are also grown in the surrounding landscape.<ref>Yementourism.com, http://www.yementourism.com/services/touristguide/detail.php?ID=2044</ref> Cheese from Taiz is also renowned throughout Yemen.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
Industries in the city of Taiz include [[cotton]]-weaving, tanning and jewelry production. Taiz today is the largest industrial base in Yemen.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}
==Transport== Taiz has many road connections with the rest of the country. The city is served by [[Ta'izz International Airport]].

'''Theodore Dwight''' (1796–1866), was an [[United States|American]] author.
==Life== Theodore Dwight was born March 3, 1796 in [[Hartford, Connecticut]]. His father was [[Theodore Dwight (elder)|Theodore Dwight]] (1764–1846) of the [[New England Dwight family]]. His mother was Abigail Alsop (1765–1846), the sister of [[Richard Alsop]] (1761–1815).<ref name="dwight1">{{cite book |author=[[Benjamin Woodbridge Dwight]] |title= The history of the descendants of John Dwight, of Dedham, Mass |volume= 1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WLfMU4yd1FYC&pg=PA265 |pages= 231–234 |year=1874 |publisher=J. F. Trow & son, printers and bookbinders }}</ref> He graduated from [[Yale College]] in 1814. He compiled the travelogues of his uncle, [[Timothy Dwight IV]], previously president of Yale, which he brought to publication in 1821. In 1825 he published the second tourist guidebook in the United States, ''The Northern Traveller,'' which he would update with regular editions until 1841.<ref name=gassan>Richard Gassan, "The First American Tourist Guidebooks: Authorship and Print Culture of the 1820s," ''Book History'' 8 (2005), pp. 51-74</ref> A commentator on American society, he wrote a number of works on child rearing, school reform, and in the 1850s and 1860s passionately advocated for the cause of [[Garibaldi]] and the unification of [[Italy]].
He married Eleanor Boyd on April 24, 1827. Their children were:<ref name="dwight1"/> # Maria Bayard Dwight was born February 17, 1828 and died February 11, 1852. # Ellen Boyd Dwight was born September 16, 1830, and married Captain Charles C. H. Kennedy, who served in the Confederate Navy during the [[American Civil War]]. # Theodore Dwight III was born March 4, 1833 but died December 18, 1852. # Mary Alsop Dwight was born March 17, 1836. # Anna Maria Dwight was born November 18, 1837, and ran a girls' school with sister Mary. # Augusta Moore Dwight was born November 18, 1840, married Sherwood Bissel Ferris. # Rebecca Jaffray Dwight was born March 1, 1842, married Fenton Rockwell, and had one child Benjamin Fenton Rockwell on December 17, 1868.
He died on October 16, 1866 in [[Brooklyn, New York]] from injuries in a train accident while traveling to [[Newark, New Jersey]].<ref name="dwight1"/> After accompanying his daughter and two grandchildren, he had jumped off the train as it left the station.<ref>{{cite news |title= The New-Jersey Railroad—The Death of Theodore Dwight |date= October 20, 1866 |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1866/10/20/83461299.pdf |format= pdf }}</ref>
== Publications == * ''A Journal of a Tour in Italy in the Year 1821 with a Description of Gibraltar' (1821) * ''The Northern Traveller'' (1825; sixth edition, 1841)<!-- "traveller" is the correct title spelling, even though US English would suggest "traveler"--> * ''First Lessons in Modern Greek'' (1833) * ''The Roman Republic of 1849'' (1851) * ''History of Connecticut'' (1841) * ''The Kansas War: or, the Exploits of Chivalry in the Nineteenth Century'' (1859) * ''Dwight's American Penny Magazine, and Family Newspaper'' later ''Dwight's American Magazine, and Family Newspaper,'' weekly, [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=wu.89066347238;view=1up;seq=7 Vol 1. No. 1], 8 February 1845 through at least [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=iau.31858053170415;view=1up;seq=821 Vol. 3, No. 52], 25 December 1847.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://mssa.library.yale.edu/obituary_record/1859_1924/1866-67.pdf ''Yale Obituary Record''] * See also Frank Luther Scott, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TIN35IEDPX8C&q=Dwight%27s#v=snippet&q=Dwight%27s&f=false ''A History of American Magazines 1740-1850''], 1966, page 364, footnote 81. {{Authority control}}

{{Chinese name|Tsiang}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Tsiang Tingfu
蔣廷黻 | image = Jiang Tingfu.jpg |image_size = 185px |birth_date = {{birth date|df=y|1895|12|7|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Shaoyang]], [[Hunan]], [[Qing dynasty]], China |death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1965|10|9|1895|12|7|mf=y}} |death_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|USA]] |nationality = Republic of China |fields = Historian |workplaces = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = Qing, Modern Chinese history |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt = |footnotes = }} {{Infobox Chinese |showflag=cp |c=蔣廷黻 |p=Jiǎng Tíngfú |myr=Jyǎng Tíngfú |mi={{IPAc-cmn|j|iang|3|-|t|ing|2|f|u|2}} |tp=Jiǎng Tíngfú |w=Ch'iang T'ingfu }} '''Tsiang Tingfu''' ({{zh|c=蔣廷黻|p=Jiǎng Tíngfú|y=Jyang Tingfu}}; 17 February 1895 – 9 October 1965) who publish in English under the name '''T.F. Tsiang''', was a historian and diplomat of the Republic of China. ==Early life and education== Tsiang was born in [[Shaoyang]] in [[Hunan Province]]. Tsiang's education from his teenage years had been Western and largely Christian, and he converted to Christianity at the age of 11. Having been urged to study in the U.S. by his teacher from a missionary school, in 1911, he was sent to study in the United States, where he attended the Park Academy, [[Oberlin College]] and [[Columbia University]]. His dissertation, "Labor and Empire: A Study of the Reaction of British Labor, Mainly as Represented in Parliament, to British Imperialism Since 1880," led him into issues in the relation of foreign relations and domestic politics which would structure his scholarship after he returned to China. After obtaining a Ph.D., he returned to China in 1923, where he first took up a position at [[Nankai University]] and then at [[Tsinghua University]].{{sfnb|Boorman|1967| p = [https://books.google.com/books?id=khJL1MRLYfoC&pg=PA355&lpg=PA355&dq=T.F.+Tsiang&source=bl&ots=fw5QTLof8u&sig=O4M_mbmR_PvS2s1_p43B9wSLNQY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjymuf_t_zbAhUl4YMKHbhaBJwQ6AEILzAB#v=onepage&q=T.F.%20Tsiang&f=false 354]}} ==Academic career== [[File:Hu Shih and Tsiang Tingfu.jpg|thumb|left|[[Hu Shih]] (right) and Tsiang (left)]]At Tsinghua, Tsiang became the head of the History Department, where he edited and published a number of works on Chinese history and edited the English-language journal ''Chinese Social and Political Science Review''. Using newly opened Qing dynasty archives and diplomatic publications, Tsiang argued that China should adopt Western approaches if it wanted to score diplomatic victories. Tsiang blamed China's unequal treatment by Western powers after the [[First Opium War]] (1839–42) on the Chinese unequal treatment of Western powers before the war. During his tenure at Tsinghua, he mentored a number of historians in the study of [[Qing]] history, including [[John K. Fairbank]]."T.F. Tsiang and Modernization," John King Fairbank, ''China Bound: A Fifty Year Memoir'' (New York: Harper & Row, 1982), 85-93 ==Diplomatic career== Following mounting tensions in China's relations with [[Japan]], Tsiang left academia in 1935 and joined the [[Chinese Nationalist]] government, which he served in many different capacities throughout the [[Second Sino-Japanese War|Sino-Japanese War]]. In 1945, Tsiang became the [[Permanent Representative of China to the United Nations]], and he subsequently also served as the ambassador of China to the United States. Following the establishment of the [[China|People's Republic of China]] on the Chinese mainland, Tsiang defended the exclusive right of the Taipei-based Republic of China to represent [[China and the United Nations|China in the United Nations]] and in the [[Security Council]]. He died of cancer in [[New York City]] on 9 October 1965, aged 69.{{cite news|title=Events From Day to Day|url=https://taiwantoday.tw/news.php?unit=4,4,29,31,31,45&post=7081|accessdate=5 April 2018|work=Taiwan Today|date=1 November 1965}} [[File:Longines Chronicles with Tsiang Tingfu 1954 ARC-96033.ogv|thumb|1954 television interview]] ==Selected writings== * Tingfu F. Tsiang, "Labor and Empire; a Study of the Reaction of British Labor, Mainly as Represented in Parliament to British Imperialism since 1880," Issued also as thesis (PH D) Columbia university Columbia university,, 1923). *"New Light on Chinese Diplomacy, 1836-49," ''[[The Journal of Modern History]]'' 3.4 (1931): 578-591. * "The Extension of Equal Commercial Privileges to Other Nations Than the British after the Treaty of Nanking," ''The Chinese Social and Political Science Review'' 15.3 (1931): 422-44. *"The Present Situation in China: A Critical Analysis," ''International Affairs'' (Royal Institute of International Affairs 1931-1939) 14.4 (1935): 496-513. * "Chinese and European Expansion," ''Politica'' 2.5 (March 1936): 1-18. * 'Zhongguo jindaishi dagang'' (Outline of Modern Chinese History) (Chongqing: Qingnian shudian, 1939; rpr. Beijing: Dongfang chubanshe, 1996). * ''Jiang Tingfu Xuanji 蔣廷黻選集 ''(Selected works of Jiang Tingfu) (Taibei: Wenxing, 1965 4 vols. Reprinted) ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{encyclopedia|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=khJL1MRLYfoC&pg=PA355&lpg=PA355&dq=T.F.+Tsiang&source=bl&ots=fw5QTLof8u&sig=O4M_mbmR_PvS2s1_p43B9wSLNQY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjymuf_t_zbAhUl4YMKHbhaBJwQ6AEILzAB#v=onepage&q=T.F.%20Tsiang&f=false |chapter = Chiang T'ing-fu |editor-first=Howard|editor-last= Boorman |title = Biographical Dictionary of Republican China Volume I |place = New York |publisher = Columbia University Press| year =1967| pp= 354-358| ref = harv}} * T.F. Tsiang, (Crystal Lorch, ed.), ''Reminiscences of Ting-fu Fuller Tsiang: Oral History'' (New York: Columbia Center for Oral History, 1965. * Charles Ronald Lilley, "Tsiang T'ing-Fu between Two Worlds, 1895-1935," (Doctoral Thesis University of Maryland, College Park, 1979). ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.bellhowell.infolearning.com/products_umi/descriptions/Tsiang-Diaries-498.shtml Description of the Tsiang Diaries] * {{Internet Archive film clip|id=gov.archives.arc.95941|description="Longines Chronoscope with Tsiang F. Tingfu"}} {{s-start}} {{s-dip}} {{Succession box |title = [[Permanent Representative of China to the United Nations|Permanent Representative and Ambassador of China to the United Nations]] |before = [[Quo Tai-chi]] |years = 1947–1962 |after = [[Liu Chieh]]}} {{s-end}} {{ChinaUNRepresentative}} {{China Ambassadors to US}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tingfu, Tsiang}} [[Category:Republic of China historians]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Oberlin College alumni]] [[Category:People from Shaoyang]] [[Category:1895 births]] [[Category:1965 deaths]] [[Category:Permanent Representatives of the Republic of China to the United Nations]] [[Category:Members of Academia Sinica]] [[Category:Ambassadors of China to the United States]] [[Category:Historians from Hunan]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:20th-century historians]] [[Category:Taiwanese people from Hunan]] [[Category:Nankai University faculty]] [[Category:Tsinghua University faculty]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New York (state)]]

{{Infobox historic engine |name = |image = Boulton & Watt steam engine, Sydney Powerhouse Museum, 2014 (15240699214).jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption = [[Boulton & Watt]] steam engine decommissioned in 1887, at the [[Powerhouse Museum]] |type = [[Watt steam engine|Watt]], [[rotative beam engine|rotative beam]] |designer = [[James Watt]] |maker = [[Boulton and Watt]] |date = {{Start date|1785}} |country_of_origin = [[England]] |former_operator = [[Whitbread]], [[London]], England |purpose = Driving brewery machinery |dimensions = |weight = |cylinders = 1 |bore = {{convert|0.64|m|in}} |stroke = {{convert|1.8|m|ft|sigfig=1}} |flywheel_diameter = {{convert|4.27|m|ft|sigfig=1}} |operating_pressure = |max_pressure = |power = {{convert|26|kW|hp|lk=out}} (as built) |collection = |location = [[Powerhouse Museum]], [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]
{{Coord|-33.877898|151.199573|display=title,inline|name=Powerhouse museum}} |accession = |url = {{URL|1=www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=7177}} |module = }} The '''Whitbread Engine''' preserved in the [[Powerhouse Museum]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]], built in 1785, is one of the first rotative [[steam engine]]s ever built, and is the oldest surviving.{{cite book|title=Historical dictionary of Sydney|first=Arthur|last=Emerson|publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=2001 |page=294 |isbn=0-8108-3999-7}} A [[rotative beam engine|rotative engine]] is a type of [[beam engine]] where the [[reciprocating motion]] of the beam is converted to [[rotation around a fixed axis|rotary motion]], producing a continuous power source suitable for driving machinery. This engine was designed by the mechanical engineer [[James Watt]], manufactured for the firm [[Boulton and Watt]] and originally installed in the [[Whitbread]] [[brewery]] in [[London]], [[England]]. On decommissioning in 1887 it was sent to Australia's Powerhouse Museum (then known as the [[Technological, Industrial and Sanitary Museum]]) and has since been restored to full working order. ==History== [[File:George Garrard, Whitbread Brewery in Chiswell Street (1792).jpg|left|thumb|The [[Whitbread]] brewery in London at the time of the engine's use.]] [[File:Sun and planet gears.gif|thumb|The [[sun and planet gear]] mechanism that converts vertical motion to rotary motion.]] The engine was ordered by [[Samuel Whitbread (1720–1796)|Samuel Whitbread]] in 1784 to replace a [[horse mill|horse wheel]] at the [[Chiswell Street]] premises of his London brewery.{{coord|51|31|14.7|N|0|5|23.8|W|display=inline|name=Whitbread brewery}} It was installed in 1785, the second steam engine to be installed in a brewery,{{cite book|title=London and the Thames Valley|page=232|first=Denis|last=Smith|publisher=Thomas Telford|year=2001|isbn=0-7277-2876-8}} and enabled Whitbread to become the largest brewer in Britain.{{cite web|url=http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/BUwhitbread.htm|title=Samuel Whitbread|publisher=Spartacus Educational|accessdate=20 March 2009}} The horse wheel was retained for many years, serving as a backup in case the steam engine broke down. The [[drive gear]] of the engine, still evident today, was connected to a series of wooden [[line shaft]]s which drove machinery within the [[brewery]]. Connected machinery included rollers to crush [[malt]]; an [[Archimedes' screw]], that lifted the crushed malt into a [[chute (gravity)|hopper]]; a [[hoist (device)|hoist]], for lifting items into the building; a three-piston [[pump]], for pumping beer; and a stirrer within a vat. There was also a reciprocating pump connected to the engine's beam, used to pump water from a [[water well|well]] to a tank on the roof of the brewery.{{cite web|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/exhibitions/boulton&watt.asp|title=The Boulton and Watt engine – Powerhouse Museum description|accessdate=13 March 2009}} In a marketing coup for both the brewer and the engine's manufacturer, [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]] and [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Queen Charlotte]] visited the brewery on 24 May 1787.{{cite web|url=http://www.londontourist.org/city%20walk%20one.html|title=The City Walk 1: Diamonds to Dungeons|publisher=The London Guide|accessdate=20 March 2009}} The engine remained in service for 102 years, until 1887. The engine made its way to the Powerhouse Museum (then known as the Technological, Industrial and Sanitary Museum) through [[Archibald Liversidge]], an English-born chemist, scientist and academic at the University of Sydney, who was a trustee of the museum.{{cite web|url=http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A050110b.htm|title=Liversidge, Archibald (1846–1927)|publisher=Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate=13 March 2009}} Liversidge was in London in 1887, at the time of the engine's decommissioning, and when he heard that the engine was to be scrapped he asked whether it could be donated to the museum.{{cite book|title=Robotics|first=Joseph A.|last=Angelo|page=389|publisher=Libraries Unlimited|year=2007|isbn=1-57356-337-4}} Whitbread & Co agreed on condition that the engine be set up and used for educational purposes.{{cite web|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=7177|title=Object: Boulton and Watt steam engine, 1785|work=Powerhouse Museum Collection Search 2.4|publisher=Powerhouse Museum|accessdate=19 March 2009}} Subsequently, the engine was dismantled and shipped to Sydney on the sailing ship ''Patriarch''. For shipping purposes, the large flywheel was divided into two halves. While the flywheel's rim could be unbolted, the hub with attached spokes had to be drilled through and rejoined after shipping. A shortage of funds meant the engine was kept in storage for several years. Eventually the engine was erected in its own engine house, behind the main building at the museum's old Harris Street premises. During the 1920s or 1930s, an electric motor was added so that people could see the engine in motion. During the 1980s the Technology Restoration Society was formed in order to raise funds for the engine's restoration. Restoration took place at the Museum's Castle Hill site. During the restoration, some parts – including the piston – were replaced to preserve the original parts.{{cite web|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/exhibitions/boulton&watt_teachers.php|title=Boulton and Watt engine – For Teachers|publisher=Powerhouse Museum|accessdate=21 December 2013}}"A dynamic object", "The 'original' piston", Information displayed at the Powerhouse Museum, 4 December 2013 The engine, restored to steaming condition, was installed in the new Powerhouse Museum in 1988. Today the engine is sometimes operated as part of the Museum's Steam Revolution exhibition,{{cite book|title=Travellers in Time |first=George |last=Gunton |page=85|publisher=Oceans Enterprises|year=1996|isbn=0-9586657-0-2}} steam being provided by the Museum's central [[boiler]]. ==Technical specifications== The engine has a {{convert|0.64|m|in}} diameter [[piston]] with a {{convert|1.8|m|ft|sigfig=1}} long [[Stroke (engine)|stroke]], driven by a [[mean effective pressure]] of {{convert|70|kPa|psi|sigfig=1}}. Its top speed is 20 [[revolutions per minute]] (rpm) of the flywheel. In the engine's youth, it had a maximum power output of approximately {{convert|26|kW|hp|lk=out}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.asme.org/Communities/History/Landmarks/Boulton_Watt_Rotative_Steam.cfm|title=Boulton & Watt Rotative Steam Engine (1785)|publisher=asme.org|accessdate=13 March 2009}} It underwent a series of alterations in 1795, converting it from [[single-acting cylinder|single-acting]] to double-acting; it was alleged at the time that this conversion improved its power to {{convert|52|kW|hp}}, but the Powerhouse Museum claims this is false.{{cite web|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=320558|title=P1306 Photograph of drawing of beam engine made in 1785 by Boulton and Watt for Whitbread's brewery, London, England, 1880s – Powerhouse Museum|accessdate=13 March 2009}} A [[centrifugal governor]], which moderates the level of steam provided if the engine begins to overload was added some years after this, and beam and main driving rod, both originally of wood, were replaced in sand-cast iron. Apart from its age, the engine is notable in that it embodies the four innovations which made Boulton & Watt's engines a significant driver of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. The first is a [[Watt steam engine#Separate condenser|separate condenser]], which increases the efficiency of the engine by allowing the main cylinder to remain hot at all times. The second is the [[parallel motion]], which converts the up-and-down motion of the piston into the arcing motion of the beam, whilst maintaining a rigid connection. The rigid connection allowed the engine to be double-acting, meaning the piston could push as well as pull the beam. Third is the [[centrifugal governor]], used to automatically regulate the speed of the engine. Finally the [[sun and planet gear]] convert the reciprocating motion of the beam into a rotating motion, which can be used to drive rotating machinery.{{cite web|first=Debbie|last=Rudder|url=http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/exhibitions/boulton&watt_transcript.asp|title=Transcript – Boulton and Watt|publisher=Powerhouse Museum|accessdate=19 March 2009}}{{cite book|title=Energy and society|first=Harold H.|last=Schobert|page=121|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2002|isbn=1-56032-767-7}} ==Cultural references== The engine is featured on the [[Bank of England note issues#.C2.A350|Bank of England £50 note]] along with [[Matthew Boulton]], James Watt, and the [[Soho Manufactory]]. {{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/steam-engine-heroes-grace-new-50-banknote|title=Steam engine heroes grace new £50 banknote|publisher=Channel 4|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=13 March 2015}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Boulton and Watt steam engine (Powerhouse Museum)|the Whitbread Engine}} * [[Murray's Hypocycloidal Engine]] – the oldest working engine with a hypocycloidal gear ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.powerhousemuseum.com/exhibitions/boulton&watt.asp The Boulton and Watt engine – Powerhouse Museum description] {{steam engine configurations}} [[Category:1785 in London]] [[Category:1785 in science]] [[Category:Preserved beam engines]] [[Category:Preserved stationary steam engines]] [[Category:Collections of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney]] [[Category:Whitbread]] [[Category:Industrial Revolution]] [[Category:History of the steam engine]] [[Category:James Watt]]
